Author: Victor Scheffer, 1906 to 2011
Quote:
Although Nature needs thousands or millions of years to create a new species, man needs only a few dozen years to destroy one.noscript
noscriptVictor Scheffer, 1906 to 2011noscript
noscriptBiologistnoscript

Author: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, 1632 to 1723
Quote:
I believe that thirty million of these animalcules together would not take up as much room, or be as big, as a coarse grain of sand.noscript
noscriptAntonie van Leeuwenhoek, 1632 to 1723noscript
noscriptBiologistnoscript

Author: Richard Dawkins, 1941 – present
Quote:
Biology is the study of the complex things in the Universe. Physics is the study of the simple ones.noscript
noscriptRichard Dawkins, 1941 – presentnoscript
noscriptEvolutionary Biologistnoscript

Author: J. B. S. Haldane, 1892 to 1964
Quote:
If physics and biology one day meet, and one of the two is swallowed up, that one will be biology.noscript
noscriptJ. B. S. Haldane, 1892 to 1964noscript
noscriptBiologistnoscript

Author: Aristotle, 384 BC to 322 BC
Quote:
By ‘life,’ we mean a thing that can nourish itself and grow and decay.noscript
noscriptAristotle, 384 BC to 322 BC noscript
noscriptScientist, Philosophernoscript

Author: Har Gobind Khorana, 1922 – 2011
Quote:
Everything that human beings or living animals do is done by protein molecules. And therefore the kind of proteins that one has and therefore the ability one has is determined by the genes that one has.noscript
noscriptHar Gobind Khorana, 1922 – 2011 noscript
noscriptMolecular Biologistnoscript

Author: Fred Hoyle, 1915 to 2001
Quote:
Instead of being the biological center of the Universe, I believe our planet is just an assembly station, but one with a major advantage over most other places. The constant presence of liquid water almost everywhere on the Earth is a huge advantage for life, especially for assembling life into complex forms by the process we call ‘evolution.’noscript
noscriptFred Hoyle, 1915 to 2001noscript
noscriptAstrophysicistnoscript

Author: James Watson, 1928 – Present
Quote:
The finding of the double helix thus brought us not only joy but great relief. It was unbelievably interesting and immediately allowed us to make a serious proposal for the mechanism of gene duplication.noscript
noscriptJames Watson, 1928 – Presentnoscript
noscriptGeneticistnoscript

Author: Francis Crick, 1916 – 2004
Quote:
The development of biology is going to destroy to some extent our traditional grounds for ethical belief and it is not easy to see what to put in their place.noscript
noscriptFrancis Crick, 1916 – 2004noscript
noscriptMolecular Biologistnoscript

Author: Stephen Jay Gould, 1941 to 2002
Quote:
Nearly 2.5 billion years of prokaryotic cells and nothing else – two-thirds of life’s history in stasis at the lowest level of recorded complexity… Why did life remain at stage 1 for two-thirds of its history if complexity offers such benefits? noscript
noscriptStephen Jay Gould, 1941 to 2002noscript
noscriptPaleontologistnoscript

Author: James Lovelock, 1919 – present
Quote:
I think it would be quite wrong to suggest that my colleagues have rejected me or that I reject them. Quite the reverse. It’s only a small, vociferous group – mainly biologists, I’m sorry to say – that go beyond ordinary scientific criticism and start becoming personal.noscript
noscriptJames Lovelock, 1919 – presentnoscript
noscriptGaia Theorist, Inventor, Scientific Polymath noscript

Author: Rachel Carson, 1907 to 1964
Quote:
This is an era of specialists, each of whom sees his own problem and is unaware of or intolerant of the larger frame into which it fits. noscript
noscriptRachel Carson, 1907 to 1964noscript
noscriptMarine Biologist noscript

Author: Bertrand Russell, 1872 – 1970
Quote:
Why the dinosaurs died out is not known, but it is supposed to be because they had minute brains and devoted themselves to the growth of weapons of offense in the shape of numerous horns.noscript
noscriptBertrand Russell, 1872 – 1970noscript
noscriptMathematician and Philosophernoscript

Author: Edmund Beecher Wilson, 1856 to 1939
Quote:
Perhaps it is not amiss to remark that the biologist may not hope to solve the ultimate problems of life any more than the chemist and physicist may hope to penetrate the final mysteries of existence in the non-living world.noscript
noscriptEdmund Beecher Wilson, 1856 to 1939noscript
noscriptGeneticist, Biologistnoscript

Author: Alfred Russel Wallace, 1823 to 1913
Quote:
All increasing or dominant species (and it is from these that new species arise) vary considerably, in all their parts, organs and faculties, in every generation.noscript
noscriptAlfred Russel Wallace, 1823 to 1913noscript
noscriptZoologist, Evolutionary Biologistnoscript

Author: Susumu Ohno, 1928 to 2000
Quote:
Did the genome of our cave-dwelling predecessors contain a set or sets of genes which enable modern man to compose music of infinite complexity and write novels with profound meaning? …It looks as though the early Homo was already provided with the intellectual potential which was in great excess of what was needed to cope with the environment of his time.”noscript
noscriptSusumu Ohno, 1928 to 2000noscript
noscriptGeneticistnoscript

Author: Auguste Compte, 1798 to 1857
Quote:
The time however has arrived when biology must, like the other sciences, make a fresh start in a purely speculative direction, free from all entanglement with medical or any other art. noscript
noscriptAuguste Compte, 1798 to 1857noscript
noscriptPhilosopher of Sciencenoscript

Author: Rita Levi-Montalcini, 1909 to 2012
Quote:
Although the alternate ‘wax and wane’ cycles are the rule rather than the exception in all fields of human endeavor, in that of biological sciences the ‘wane’ is all too often indicative of a justified loss of faith in the rational and methodical approach that had at first raised so much hope. noscript
noscriptRita Levi-Montalcini, 1909 to 2012noscript
noscriptNeurobiologistnoscript

Author: Stan Ulam, 1909 – 1984
Quote:
I believe that new mathematical schemata, new systems of axioms, certainly new systems of mathematical structures will be suggested by the study of the living world.noscript
noscriptStan Ulam, 1909 – 1984noscript
noscriptMathematiciannoscript

Author: Shinya Yamanaka, 1962 to Present
Quote:
Dr. Ikemoto repeatedly told me that we should not perform research that simply reproduced somebody else’s results. Rather, we should do something unique and new. noscript
noscriptShinya Yamanaka, 1962 to Presentnoscript
noscriptStem Cell Biologistnoscript

Author: Stephen Jay Gould, 1941 to 2002
Quote:
“Evolution is one of the half-dozen shattering ideas that science has developed to overturn past hopes and assumptions, and to enlighten our current thoughts.” noscript
noscriptStephen Jay Gould, 1941 to 2002noscript
noscriptPaleontologistnoscript

Author: Charles Darwin, 1809 to 1882
Quote:
On the principle of successive variations not always supervening at an early age, and being inherited at a corresponding not early period of life, we can clearly see why the embryos of mammals, birds, reptiles, and fishes should be so closely alike, and should be so unlike the adult forms. noscript
noscriptCharles Darwin, 1809 to 1882noscript
noscriptNaturalist, Evolutionary Biologistnoscript

Author: Carl Sagan, 1934 to 1996
Quote:
Our thoughts, visions and fantasies have a physical reality. A thought is made of hundreds of electrochemical impulses.noscript
noscriptCarl Sagan, 1934 to 1996noscript
noscriptAstrobiologist, Planetary Scientistnoscript

Author: Herbert Maule Richards, 1871 to 1928
Quote:
Botany consists in the gathering of plants, and the dismembering of them, in connection with the use of a complicated terminology. That is the beginning and end of botany as it is understood by the majority.noscript
noscriptHerbert Maule Richards, 1871 to 1928noscript
noscriptBotanistnoscript

Author: Svante Arrhenius, 1859 to 1927
Quote:
It is thus probable that germs of the lowest organisms known to us are continually being carried away from the earth and the other planets upon which they exist. As seeds in general, so most of these spores, thus carried away, will no doubt meet death in the cold infinite space of the universe. Yet a small number of spores will fall on some other world, and may there be able to spread life, if conditions be suitable.noscript
noscriptSvante Arrhenius, 1859 to 1927noscript
noscriptPhysical Chemistnoscript
